name: Ragtime
description: Emerged in the 1890s; piano-led and characterized by a heavily syncopated rhythm.

children.name: Cakewalk
children.description: Typically in 2/4 time with a distinctive "oompah" rhythm, named for a dance created by enslaved Black Americans as a mockery of the social dances of white slaveholders.

children.name: Classic Ragtime
children.description: Draws on the complexity and formal structures of Western Classical Music, cycling through multiple strains (themes); emerged from Missouri's Sedalia school.

children.name: Honky-Tonk Piano
children.description: Nostalgic revival popularised in the 1950s which is more upbeat and whimsical, with a bright and detuned piano sound.

children.name: Novelty Piano
children.description: Popular in the 1920s; originated in Chicago and took influence from Jazz.

children.name: Ragtime Song
children.description: Incorporates syncopated, "ragged" rhythms into popular song forms.

children.name: Stride
children.description: Early form of Ragtime-derived Jazz with improvisational tendencies; named for the performers' left hand "striding" across the piano keyboard.
